articles.headline: Lawyer Put Health Act in Peril by Pointing Out 4 Little Words
articles.snippet: Thomas Christina, a lawyer from Greenville, S.C., unearthed the language about tax credits that fueled a case that will be heard by the Supreme Court on Wednesday.
articles.abstract: Thomas Christina, a lawyer from Greenville, S.C., unearthed the language about tax credits that fueled a case that will be heard by the Supreme Court on Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The first lawsuits challenging the Affordable Care Act were still in the early stages, but conservative lawyers were already working on a backup plan in December 2010 if the first line of attack failed.

articles.headline: A Thin Line of Defense Against ‘Honor Killings’
articles.snippet: Women’s shelters are one of the most provocative legacies of the Western presence in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: Women’s shelters are one of the most provocative legacies of the Western presence in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Faheema stood trembling in the courtyard of the large house, steeling herself for the meeting with her family.

articles.headline: Britain’s Elite Still Enjoying a Tax Break 100 Years Old
articles.snippet: A growing number of the wealthy British residents do not have to pay tax on their foreign income or assets, thanks to an Edwardian-era law.
articles.abstract: A growing number of the wealthy British residents do not have to pay tax on their foreign income or assets, thanks to an Edwardian-era law.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — They are among the British moneyed elite: the head of the nation’s largest bank, a billionaire hedge fund manager and the owner of some of London’s most luxurious nightclubs.

articles.headline: Saving Big on Energy Bills, People Take It to the Bank
articles.snippet: Energy prices began falling last summer, but economists are stumped on what consumers are doing with the extra money. They’re not shopping.
articles.abstract: Energy prices began falling last summer, but economists are stumped on what consumers are doing with the extra money. They’re not shopping.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sometimes, even the supposed experts can lose track of a billion dollars or two. Or, in this case, $100 billion.

articles.headline: At JPMorgan Chase, Business Tilts Toward the Consumer Side and Away From Wall St.
articles.snippet: The diverging prospects for JPMorgan’s biggest businesses are reflective of a split within the broader financial industry.
articles.abstract: The diverging prospects for JPMorgan’s biggest businesses are reflective of a split within the broader financial industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: A reversal of fortunes within the financial industry is illustrated in few places more vividly than JPMorgan Chase.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Used Personal Email Account at State Dept., Possibly Breaking Rules
articles.snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton did not have a government email address while secretary of state and may have violated federal rules that officials’ correspondence be retained.
articles.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton did not have a government email address while secretary of state and may have violated federal rules that officials’ correspondence be retained.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hillary Rodham Clinton exclusively used a personal email account to conduct government business as secretary of state, State Department officials said, and may have violated federal requirements that officials’ correspondence be retained as part of the agency’s record.

articles.headline: A Warning From Buffett About Banks
articles.snippet: Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire chairman of Berkshire Hathaway, has released his annual shareholder letter, and it is unusually critical of the financial industry.
articles.abstract: Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire chairman of Berkshire Hathaway, has released his annual shareholder letter, and it is unusually critical of the financial industry.

articles.headline: Some Owners of Private Colleges Turn a Tidy Profit by Going Nonprofit
articles.snippet: Under a government crackdown on for-profit schools that leave students with useless credentials and punishing debt, some colleges have converted to nonprofits, in lucrative deals.
articles.abstract: Under a government crackdown on for-profit schools that leave students with useless credentials and punishing debt, some colleges have converted to nonprofits, in lucrative deals.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a recent government crackdown on the multibillion-dollar career-training industry, stricter limits on student aid and devastating publicity about students hobbled by debt and useless credentials, some for-profit schools simply shut down.

articles.headline: In Congress, Netanyahu Faults ‘Bad Deal’ on Iran Nuclear Program
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said that negotiations over Iran’s nuclear program were proceeding on a false hope that Iran is acting in good faith. President Obama dismissed the speech as “theater.”
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said that negotiations over Iran’s nuclear program were proceeding on a false hope that Iran is acting in good faith. President Obama dismissed the speech as “theater.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With dark warnings and a call to action, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel used one of the world’s most prominent venues on Tuesday to denounce what he called a “bad deal” being negotiated with Iran and to mount an audacious challenge to President Obama.

articles.headline: House Approves Homeland Security Budget, Without Strings
articles.snippet: The move by Speaker John A. Boehner, surprising in its timing, averted a partial shutdown of the Department of Homeland Security but inflamed conservatives.
articles.abstract: The move by Speaker John A. Boehner, surprising in its timing, averted a partial shutdown of the Department of Homeland Security but inflamed conservatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The fight over funding the Department of Homeland Security that began with Republicans thundering about a lawless president abusing power to change immigration policy ended with a quiet capitulation Tuesday when the House voted to fund the agency and avert a partial shutdown.
